claim: There are exactly seven symptomatic patients within the normal IgG group.
extra_info: normal Ig G level refers to IGG > 900 and IGG < 2000; have symptoms refers to Symptoms IS NOT NULL;
reasoning: The claim states there are exactly seven symptomatic patients in the normal IgG group (IGG > 900 AND IGG < 2000 with Symptoms IS NOT NULL). Querying the database by joining Laboratory and Examination tables shows only 1 distinct patient (ID 1567380) meets these criteria, not seven.

content.text: I'll verify this claim step by step.

content.content:
CREATE TABLE Examination
(
    ID                 INTEGER          null,
    `Examination Date` DATE         null,
    `aCL IgG`          REAL        null,
    `aCL IgM`          REAL        null,
    ANA                INTEGER          null,
    `ANA Pattern`      TEXT null,
    `aCL IgA`          INTEGER          null,
    Diagnosis          TEXT null,
    KCT                TEXT null,
    RVVT              TEXT null,
    LAC                TEXT null,
    Symptoms           TEXT null,
    Thrombosis         INTEGER          null,
    foreign key (ID) references Patient (ID)
            on update cascade on delete cascade
);
CREATE TABLE Patient
(
    ID           INTEGER default 0 not null
        primary key,
    SEX          TEXT  null,
    Birthday     DATE          null,
    Description  DATE          null,
    `First Date` DATE          null,
    Admission    TEXT  null,
    Diagnosis    TEXT  null
);
CREATE TABLE Laboratory
(
    ID        INTEGER  default 0            not null,
    Date      DATE default '0000-00-00' not null,
    GOT       INTEGER                       null,
    GPT       INTEGER                        null,
    LDH       INTEGER                        null,
    ALP       INTEGER                        null,
    TP        REAL             null,
    ALB       REAL             null,
    UA        REAL             null,
    UN        INTEGER                       null,
    CRE       REAL             null,
    `T-BIL`   REAL             null,
    `T-CHO`   INTEGER                       null,
    TG        INTEGER                       null,
    CPK       INTEGER                       null,
    GLU       INTEGER                       null,
    WBC       REAL             null,
    RBC       REAL             null,
    HGB       REAL             null,
    HCT       REAL             null,
    PLT       INTEGER                       null,
    PT        REAL             null,
    APTT      INTEGER                       null,
    FG        REAL             null,
    PIC       INTEGER                       null,
    TAT       INTEGER                       null,
    TAT2      INTEGER                       null,
    `U-PRO`   TEXT              null,
    IGG       INTEGER                       null,
    IGA       INTEGER                       null,
    IGM       INTEGER                       null,
    CRP       TEXT              null,
    RA        TEXT              null,
    RF        TEXT              null,
    C3        INTEGER                       null,
    C4        INTEGER                       null,
    RNP       TEXT              null,
    SM        TEXT              null,
    SC170     TEXT              null,
    SSA       TEXT              null,
    SSB       TEXT              null,
    CENTROMEA TEXT              null,
    DNA       TEXT              null,
    `DNA-II`  INTEGER                       null,
    primary key (ID, Date),
        foreign key (ID) references Patient (ID)
            on update cascade on delete cascade
);

content.text: Now I can see the schema. `IGG` is in the `Laboratory` table and `Symptoms` is in the `Examination` table. I need to find patients with normal IgG (900 < IGG < 2000) who have symptoms (Symptoms IS NOT NULL).

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/thrombosis_prediction.sqlite" "SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT L.ID) FROM Laboratory L INNER JOIN Examination E ON L.ID = E.ID WHERE L.IGG > 900 AND L.IGG < 2000 AND E.Symptoms IS NOT NULL;"
input.description: Count symptomatic patients with normal IgG

content.text: That gives only 1. Let me reconsider — maybe "normal IgG group" means patients who have at least one lab record with normal IGG, and "symptomatic" means they have at least one examination with symptoms. Let me also check if the join condition matters, i.e., whether symptoms and IGG need to be from the same record or just the same patient.

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/thrombosis_prediction.sqlite" "SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT E.ID) FROM Examination E WHERE E.Symptoms IS NOT NULL AND E.ID IN (SELECT DISTINCT ID FROM Laboratory WHERE IGG > 900 AND IGG < 2000);"
input.description: Count symptomatic patients in normal IgG group (any lab record)

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/thrombosis_prediction.sqlite" "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Examination E INNER JOIN Laboratory L ON E.ID = L.ID WHERE L.IGG > 900 AND L.IGG < 2000 AND E.Symptoms IS NOT NULL;"
input.description: Count rows (not distinct) with normal IgG and symptoms

content.text: Let me also check with >= and <= in case the hint means inclusive bounds:

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/thrombosis_prediction.sqlite" "SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT L.ID) FROM Laboratory L INNER JOIN Examination E ON L.ID = E.ID WHERE L.IGG >= 900 AND L.IGG <= 2000 AND E.Symptoms IS NOT NULL;"

sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/thrombosis_prediction.sqlite" "SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT E.ID) FROM Examination E WHERE E.Symptoms IS NOT NULL AND E.ID IN (SELECT DISTINCT ID FROM Laboratory WHERE IGG >= 900 AND IGG <= 2000);"
input.description: Count with inclusive bounds, any lab record

content.text: The count is 1 with distinct patients, not 7. Let me also check if `Symptoms` could have empty strings that should be treated differently:

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/thrombosis_prediction.sqlite" "SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT E.ID) FROM Examination E WHERE E.Symptoms IS NOT NULL AND E.Symptoms != '' AND E.ID IN (SELECT DISTINCT ID FROM Laboratory WHERE IGG > 900 AND IGG < 2000);"

content.text:
Only one patient (ID 1567380) has symptoms and is in the normal IgG group. The claim states there are exactly seven such patients, but the data shows only one.

Let me do one more check — perhaps the claim is counting examination records (rows), not distinct patients:

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/thrombosis_prediction.sqlite" "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Examination E WHERE E.Symptoms IS NOT NULL AND E.ID IN (SELECT DISTINCT ID FROM Laboratory WHERE IGG > 900 AND IGG < 2000);"
input.description: Count examination rows for symptomatic patients in normal IgG group

content.text:
Still 1. The claim of exactly seven is contradicted by the data.
